title: Maury Povich on those famous paternity tests: 'I'm as surprised as they are'
text:
CLOSE

NBC105 1/8/2000 Premieres Sunday, January 9 (8-9 p.m. ET) Twenty One -- NBC Game Show -- Pictured: Maury Povich, host -- NBC Photo: David Bjerke ORG XMIT: NBC105 (Photo: DAVID BJERKE, NBC)

Maury Povich is opening up about those famous paternity tests that audiences have grown to love on his talk show "Maury."

In an interview with Entertainment Tonight, the talk show host, 80, revealed the inception of how the successful tests were brought onto the show.

"They said, 'We have this idea. We want to do paternity tests, and we can have a result within 10 or 12 minutes,'" Povich said. "And the audience, all they're looking for is a result. You build that up with the drama."

Povich said he wanted his reactions to the tests to be genuine, so he doesn't know the results before anyone in the audience.

"I said, 'I don't wanna know the result (beforehand). I don't wanna know anything more than my guests. I don't wanna think anything more than my audience. My live audience, my audience at home. If I know the answer, I will skew my questions,'" he said. "And that was the key… because I'm as surprised as they are!"

And the success shows, according to ET, which reports Povich only works two days a week and makes an estimated $13 million per year. "Maury" first aired in 1991.

As for Povich, he considers himself a TV "survivor."

"There are 75 daytime talk shows in the graveyard, so you worry about that all the time," he said. "You just don't want to go to the cemetery."
